content.intro:
Revolution is permanent in San Francisco, a pacifist revolution, in this case, that for 50 years has been inventing ideas and transforming the world.

It is hard to imagine the end of the world in San Francisco. Life can be heard in the rustle of the waves, in the song of the gulls, or seen in the undulations of its hills. This town anchored on the Pacific coast is ‘subliminally' seismic, in perpetual motion. The earthquake that partly destroyed the city in 1906 has been reproduced multiple times, figuratively, with the city making waves that radiate across the planet. Many movements that have put Western societies in tumult were born in its bay. San Francisco started the hippie movement, introduced the New Age, and is giving birth to new technologies as we speak. The city is opening new doors in its commitment to sustainable development and ecology. Brains in Silicon Valley are busy imagining a better world, a fully green world.
All this would have seduced Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg, whose heirs have made vegetarianism a lifestyle as modern and urban as digital start-ups. In Oshkosh overalls and plaid shirts, you will recognize the new-world adventurers in the hip parts of town. No area in the US has as many small organic farms. San Francisco inspires new culinary trends; its restaurants become models even for major chefs. Nowadays one guru, food journalist and Berkeley grad Michael Pollan, summarises the current ‘forward-looking' food trend as a return to the past: ‘Do not eat anything your grandmother wouldn't recognise as food', he has said.
Dirty Harry, Vertigo, Bullitt—San Francisco has been the scene of many a movie set. Its iconic tramways and disparate neighbourhoods are themselves the ‘stars' of films so well known you will have the impression you too are walking across the screen.
The highways that lead you out of the city take you towards landscapes so beautiful, so wild, they make all dreams seem possible on this pristine preserved coastline so rock solid no storm can overwhelm it. Indeed, here is a place that lends itself to the discovery of the work of the first environmentalist poet Henry David Thoreau and of his follower, John Muir, who helped protect the Sierra Nevada mountains just inland. When you're perfectly comfortable in a small cove with a view of sea lions and seals languidly lazing about, pick up your copy of Walden. The ocean here regenerates you, relieving you of your bad vibes. No body of water bears its name so well. Looking out over the Pacific, you will feel invaded by peace.

content.title: Psychedelic adventure at Magowan's Infinite Mirror Maze

introduction.small: In San Francisco, this attraction revisits the classic houses of mirrors with neon colours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Psychedelic adventure at Magowan's Infinite Mirror Maze

paragraphs.text:
Usually the hit attraction of any fair of old, the seemingly endless house of mirrors finds its concept upped to the tenth here: plunged in darkness, the path takes on a psychedelic overtone, using neon lights and funky 80s music. Perfect for building strong family relationship or a fun afternoon among friends, Magowan's Infinite Mirror Maze is a favourite of San Franciscans, where they know an extraordinary experience awaits. Proceed among the 77 mirrors, lit in an artistic fashion, and question the reality of your reflection – unless it be an illusion? In the meantime, the youngest visitors will somehow try to find their way out through the maze. The hallucinatory nature of the show will last for as long as you let it, but let's face it: losing oneself has never been that much fun!

Magowan's Infinite Mirror Maze
Pier 39
San Francisco, CA 94111

Tel : +1 415 835 0019

www.magowansinfinitemirrormaze.com

content.title: Hotel Zoe Fisherman's Wharf, like a power cruiser

introduction.small: This hotel stands near San Francisco's Pier 39. An ideal location to walk up and down the city from its touristic centre onwards.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Zoe Fisherman's Wharf, like a power cruiser

paragraphs.text:
The sea spray that reaches the windows of Hotel Zoe Fisherman's Wharf will definitely make you feel like you are on a cruise boat. The corridors have been designed to emulate the passageways of luxury yachts, with beige fitted carpets and walls, while the 221 rooms reveal a cabin look. Their contemporary design, with a prevalence of blond wood and iron, contrasts with Edwardian furniture. Some rooms even offer a fireplace! This singular combination gives the hotel a sophisticated charm, similar to what you would find in high-end establishments, only for a sliver of the price. Located in the heart of San Francisco and next to the main tourist attractions, you will definitely enjoy the ease of access. A perfect solution to drop the car and explore the city on foot or trolley.

Hotel Zoe Fisherman's Wharf
425 North Point Street
San Francisco, CA 94133

Tel : +1 415 561 1100

www.hotelzoesf.com

Chambre : à partir de 149 USD

content.title: Che Fico, the Italian tavern in all its splendour

introduction.small: Mediterranean decoration, heartwarming cuisine and comforting atmosphere, here's what you should expect at Che fico.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Che Fico, the Italian tavern in all its splendour

paragraphs.text:
Located on the second floor of an old body shop, it takes walking up a staircase decorated with bright-coloured tiles to access the gigantic dining room. Once up there, you will almost forget you are in the very heart of San Francisco. Very high white ceilings, an L-shaped bar and the bright and spacious dining room all hark back to the spirit of Italian trattorie.
The mouth-watering scent of dishes being baked in the huge pizza oven fills up the entire restaurant. A gigantic storeroom full of food stands at the centre of the inn, and children love to peep at it during the meal.
Try the mushroom pizza, the chef's speciality. Pasta is also a pure delight, perfectly seasoned. The farfalle with tomato sauce in particular will hold your attention, light and meltingly soft. The perfect pairing – in moderation – will come in the form of sophisticated cocktails, like a punch, mixing pineapple black pepper, cinnamon and cognac. Additionally, you will find a fine Italian wine selection. Italy has never felt this close to San Francisco that at Che Fico.

Che Fico
838 Divisadero Street
San Francisco, CA 94117

+1 415 416 6959

www.chefico.com

Menu: from 40 USD

content.title: Wooden Spoon, perfect meeting spot for a brunch

introduction.small: From breakfast till tea time, Wooden Spoon has established itself as the new HQ of trendy youth looking for coffee and a sweet note.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wooden Spoon, perfect meeting spot for a brunch

paragraphs.text:
Care for a brunch? Or lunch with salads, sandwiches and various tapas platters to share? Then this place will become your new sanctuary, thanks to generous and colourful servings. In an elegant and refined decor that instantly puts you at ease, the atmosphere feels warm and laid back, with wooden spoons being displayed everywhere on the walls. Enjoy a cocktail – in moderation – or a smoothie according to your mood (and depending on the time), or, why not, a simple yet comforting cup of coffee… anything goes! On the menu, the Blue Green Smoothie Bowl (banana, pineapple, hemp seeds, buckwheat granola and various seasonal fruits) mixes cereals and fruits for a high-energy drink, ideal when you're feeling low on energy. If you are having brunch, indulge in the Big Spoon (eggs, bacon, potatoes, toast, pancakes and veggies), a full plate to start off the day with a bang. It's a fact, Wooden Spoon brings satisfaction to all late-morning comers.

Wooden Spoon
2172 Market Street
San Francisco, CA 94114

+1 415 946 3005

www.woodenspoonsf.com

Menu: between 8 and 30 USD

content.title: Birdsong SF, an ode to San Francisco's local cuisine

introduction.small: Far from the fusion gastronomy modern tendencies, Birdsong SF gives pride of place to the typical cuisine of the San Francisco Bay area.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Birdsong SF, an ode to San Francisco's local cuisine

paragraphs.text:
With its wooden logs, turquoise facade and country-like aspect, the place stands out from the SoMa neighbourhood, new hotspot of San Francisco's tech area. The goal of chef Chris Bleidorn is to pay tribute to the cuisine of the west coast, using ingredients directly supplied by regional producers. Installed on turquoise bench seats in an intimate dining room around the open-plan kitchen, food lovers are being offered two different menus, changing according to the season: the 5-course one is available on week days only, and the tasting menu counts no less than 13 dishes! High-quality products such as venison and buffalo meat are at the centre of the culinary experience devised by the chef. With a decoration reminiscent of the old speakeasies where wood is everywhere, Birdsong SF provides the perfect atmosphere to enjoy this typically local gastronomy.

Birdsong SF
1085 Mission Street
San Francisco, CA 94103

+1 415 369 9161

www.birdsongsf.com

Menu: from 120 USD

content.title: Local Edition, a bar with the atmosphere of a speakeasy

introduction.small: Escape for an evening in a San Franciscan subterranean hideaway to enjoy delicious forbidden cocktails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Local Edition, a bar with the atmosphere of a speakeasy

paragraphs.text:
Prohibition is over in the United States, but some addresses keep this secret that surrounded bars. Located in the basement of a building in a former newspaper printing press, Local Edition is among such speakeasies. It has built upon the place's history by scattering vintage paper presses and clippings here and there. Its 1950s decor, with dim lighting and jazz music, immerses you directly in a special atmosphere. In addition, you will have to keep your eyes peeled to get there. The entrance, located on Market Street, is not easy to find. Small clue: turn to the clock in the window of number 691.
Make your way to the bar to order one of the many cocktails that the
bartenders craft to perfection. The Bad Moon Ryesing, made of Suze, lime,lychee shrub and vanilla and cinnamon infused Laphroaig, is excellent, as is the Mother Superior, composed of San Francisco's very own Junipero gin, lemon juice, coriander, tonic and grapefruit peel – as always, to be consumed in moderation!

Local Edition
691 Market Street
San Francisco, CA 94105

+1 415 795 1375

www.localeditionsf.com

Cocktails: from 12 USD

content.title: Unconventionality at Zeppelin Hotel

introduction.small: San Francisco is full of stylish hotels, but Zeppelin Hotel, as beautiful as it is, is far from looking like any other and sets itself apart with its astonishing characteristics.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Unconventionality at Zeppelin Hotel

paragraphs.text:
At the foot of Nob Hill, one of San Francisco's 43 hills, is an impressive hotel. Zeppelin Hotel belongs to the Viceroy Hotel Group and reflects the spirit of the bay city: unconventional.
Raw materials are predominant in the 196 rooms and common areas: wood, leather, zinc… The colours are sombre: purple, imperial green, grey and red. But that doesn't prevent the rooms from being bright, thanks to touches of white and large windows. As soon as you walk through the door at Zeppelin Hotel, you will immediately feel good. You will love relaxing on the velvet sofas in the bar, to the sound of a vinyl on the record deck.
In the evening, the Rambler restaurant is the perfect place to unwind after a long day: alongside brick walls, enjoy a pizza baked in a wood-fired oven, or a classic yet delicious creamed spinach.

Zeppelin Hotel
545 Post Street
San Francisco, CA 94102

+1 415 563 0303

www.viceroyhotelsandresorts.com/en/zeppelin

Rooms: from 180 USD

content.title: SFMOMA, a prerequisite for culture lovers

introduction.small: First museum dedicated to modern and contemporary art on the west coast, this is a must-see during your stay in Frisco.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: SFMOMA, a prerequisite for culture lovers

paragraphs.text:
Between the tall buildings of San Francisco, the Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA) is like no other: you cannot miss its distinctive architecture, characterised by its graphic facade. Opened in 1935, it was the first museum dedicated to this theme on this side of the United States. In 2016, major works were done enabling the museum to triple its area, over 4,000 sqm of which is accessible free of charge.
The establishment is divided into four spaces: one dedicated to architecture and design, a second to media arts, a third to painting and sculpture and the last devoted to photography. Designed one on top of the other, exhibition spaces welcome distinct universes, extended by terraces and sculptures gardens. The facade appears to mimic the fog effects and light changes in San Francisco Bay. Above all, the goal was to create a link between spaces. Here, many artists, more or less well-known, are exposed. For example, you will have the opportunity to admire the works of Henri Cartier-Bresson, Edvard Munch, Otto Dix and Irving Penn, each of which is magnificently highlighted by the architecture.

San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA)
151 Third Street
San Francisco, CA 94103

+1 415 357 4000

www.sfmoma.org

content.title: Discover the city differently aboard the cable cars

introduction.small: From the bottom to the top of San Francisco's hills, ride the cable cars, a means of transportation from another time, and discover the city's most beautiful addresses.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the city differently aboard the cable cars

paragraphs.text:
Cable cars were put into service in 1873 to transport San Franciscans up and down the hills and steep descents without much effort – the city once had 43 hills. Today, only three remain, which have become one of the major tourist attractions of “Frisco”. Go for a ride in the cable cars, for an authentic and romance-filled discovery.
The Powell/Mason line gives you a view of Lombard Street and its hairpin turns, as does the Powell/Hyde line which, as a bonus, provides panoramic views of the old Alcatraz prison. The third, California line, climbs Nob Hills, from which you will enjoy one of the most beautiful views of San Francisco. A very nice way to discover the Californian megalopolis in a very different manner.
The most curious will continue their journey to the Cable Car Museum: entirely free, you will learn about the history of the tramways and can admire antique cable cars.

Cable Car Museum San Francisco
1201 Mason Street
San Francisco, CA 94108

+1 415 474 1887

www.cablecarmuseum.org

content.title: The Castro Theatre, more than a neighbourhood cinema

introduction.small: An architectural jewel where cinema festivals, receptions and evenings of all kinds are organised—visiting the Castro Theatre is a must in San Francisco.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Castro Theatre, more than a neighbourhood cinema

paragraphs.text:
Built in 1922 by architect Timothy L. Pflueger, the Castro Theatre is one of the few early 20th-century cinemas in the country to still be in operation. Note the Mexican, Spanish and Arabic influences seen in the mouldings and arabesques that decorate the interior facades of the lobby. Large gold-framed mirrors hang above the two main staircases and the walls are decorated with movie posters.

The screening room, meanwhile, has a warm atmosphere where you will find traditional red velvet seats. An organ player will even entertain you with an impressive instrument before the beginning of the film. Then the curtain will rise, making way for the big screen. Discover programming that suits all tastes, mixing old auteur films and modern productions. You can also attend festivals, musicals and even sing-a-long nights!

Castro Theatre
429 Castro Street
San Francisco, CA 94114

+1 415 621 6120

www.castrotheatre.com

content.title: Saison, gastronomy on a fire hearth

introduction.small: Fire is the little plus of chef Joshua Skenes at the head of San Francisco's Saison restaurant with three Michelin stars.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saison, gastronomy on a fire hearth

paragraphs.text:
“Cooking elevated to an art form”. This is how the Michelin Guide defines Chef Skenes' style. Saison is without a doubt the star restaurant in San Francisco today. In a minimalist atmosphere reminiscent of Scandinavia, the chef works daily to serve seasonal cuisine (indeed Saison means ‘season' in French). The flavours are both refined and powerful, and these modern dishes are enhanced by their cooking over a wood fire.

The establishment is worthy of the greatest French restaurants. In the kitchen, the brass pots dash here and there; in the dining room, the waiters explain each dish, each ingredient and each wine that accompanies them. On the menu there is caviar, chicken, veal, beef and shellfish, but you will only see the dishes when they arrive at your table, the chef likes to keep his secret garden. Choose the tasting menu that will provide a good example of his know-how. The next day you can boast of having had dinner at the best restaurant on the west coast.

Saison
178 Townsend Street
San Francisco, CA 94107

+1 415 828 7990

www.saisonsf.com

Menu: around 150 USD

content.title: Tailor-made San Francisco & Napa Valley wine experience

introduction.small: A bespoke tour to explore hilly San Francisco and taste outstanding vintages at some of the most celebrated Napa Valley wineries in California's wine country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tailor-made San Francisco & Napa Valley wine experience

paragraphs.text:
Start off your Californian escapade in San Francisco, a city known for its openness, its architectural imprint and cosmopolitan makeup. Take a short but exhilarating ride on the picturesque cable car to marvel at the diversity of neighbourhoods and the steep urban landscape. As the sun goes down, board a sailboat on the San Francisco Bay to get unparalleled views of Alcatraz and the Golden Gate bridge.
After this city break, head off to wine country to discover the cellars thathave put this region on the international wine map. Enjoy the contrast of theblue skies against the seemingly endless vines or admire them from a bird's-eye perspective aboard a hot-air balloon.
Taste sought-after red wines at world-class Napa wineries the likes of Opus One or Château Montelena of 1976 Judgment of Paris' fame. Spend the afternoon at a local golf course or take part in a hands-on culinary workshop to round off this one-of-a-kind "city & vines" experience.

Wine Paths

+33 (0)5 57 78 43 47

Discover more about this exclusive San Francisco and Napa Valley Wine Tour

content.title: Time to meditate at the Japanese Tea Garden

introduction.small: Head over to the Golden Gate Park to discover this haven of rest and taste a delicious drop of tea.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Time to meditate at the Japanese Tea Garden

paragraphs.text:
Opened in 1894, this Japanese tea garden is the oldest in the United States and was created by famous landscape gardener Makoto Hagiwara. According to legend, he invented the famed Chinese fortune cookies here for the 1915 Exposition. Make sure you come and taste them, along with an authentic Japanese tea. Before partaking in the tea ceremony, you can wash your hands in a small basin in the form of a boat right near the shop.
Bonsais, ponds, pagodas, stone lanterns, zen gardens and tea shops, allare set out in pure Japanese style. You can even admire an impressive 10-feet (3 meters) high bronze Buddha statue that was made in Japan in 1790.

Japanese Tea Garden
75 Hagiwara Tea Garden Drive
Golden Gate Park
San Francisco, CA 94118

+1 415 752 4227

https://www.japaneseteagardensf.com/

content.title: The Palace Hotel, modern and authentic

introduction.small: Among the first American palaces ever built, the Palace Hotel offers a setting of unparalleled elegance since 1875.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Palace Hotel, modern and authentic

paragraphs.text:
Announcing the technological avant-garde trends of San Francisco, in the heart of the business quarter, the ambitious Palace Hotel of William Chapman Ralston offers 556 rooms, all sumptuous, topped with mouldings and centenary woodwork, with four-metre high ceilings and marble bathrooms. The decor is both modern and authentic with furniture inspired by luxury baggage and textiles with diverse tones of grey and blue.
Following long repair work due to the Great San Francisco Fire of 1906, the Palace regained its majesty with the construction of the Garden Court: an immense dining room bathed in light thanks to 70,000 glass panes and a multitude of chandeliers in Austrian crystal where you can dine in magnificence. Feeling like a break? On the fourth floor, take a dive into a pool overlooked by a clear dome and admire the nearby skyscrapers.

Palace Hotel
2 New Montgomery Street
San Francisco, CA 94105

+1 415 512 1111

www.sfpalace.com

Rooms: from 280 USD

content.title: Outerlands - offshore winds deep in Sunset

introduction.small: The fragrance of good bread, steaming soup and homemade cakes – a place for vegans, locavores and food-lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Outerlands - offshore winds deep in Sunset

paragraphs.text:
Enjoy a stroll on Ocean Beach before booking a table in an area that attracts the finest surfers. It is a 45-minute bus ride from Market to the terminus, during which you look at pastel-coloured houses scrolling past. You will not be disappointed. At the far end of Judah Street, a few blocks from the beach, chefs Yoni Levy and Brooke Mosley serve simple and inventive locavore cuisine. This haven of good taste, with its weathered wooden slats, serves freshly baked sourdough bread (which you can order takeaway), homemade vegetable soup, roasted squash and garlic, and bacon pancakes. It is a little bit vegan, which is normal in California. The menu changes according to whatever small producers have available, and there are tasty surprises like the irresistible fig, honey and sherry vinegar panna cotta for dessert.

Outerlands
4001 Judah Street
San Francisco, CA 94122

+1 415 661 6140

www.outerlandssf.com

Menu: around 26 USD

content.title: Linda Mar Beach: right in the waves

introduction.small: It is impossible to come to San Francisco without diving into the waves or at least admiring them from the shore! Surf culture was born in California, a rendezvous for all surfers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Linda Mar Beach: right in the waves

paragraphs.text:
You can surf in San Mateo, south of San Francisco, where waves can reach up to 24 metres high in winter and where international surfers meet for Big Wave Surfing, the most important competition in the world.

Further north, immediately after Sausalito and 30 minutes from the Golden Gate Bridge, you arrive at Linda Mar Beach, a sublime beach that has the advantage of being protected from fog, even in the summer. Everything is provided for your comfort. Parking, showers, equipment hire, and the essential wetsuit, because the sea is cold.

Whether you are a beginner or an expert, you will face the waves with as much pleasure as you will have chills. If you are neither, you can also take your first lesson or just enjoy the beach, with its small bars and good restaurants. Before you go, ask about the marine weather forecast. Know that the best winds are from the south-east, there are more tidal waves than swell, and that the best rollers are those coming from the north-west.

Linda Mar Beach
Pacifica State Beach
5000 Pacific Coast Hwy
Pacifica, CA 94044

+1 650 738 7381

content.title: Silicon Valley: incubator of genius

introduction.small: The brains of Silicon Valley have set the world afire digitally, and now they are looking to start us towards an ecological future.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Silicon Valley: incubator of genius

paragraphs.text:
San Jose is the capital of the Silicon Valley, south of San Francisco. Steve Wozniak, the designer of the first Apple computers, is from here. San Jose is now one of the most active and the committed cities to ideas of innovation and ecological conversion.

Incubation cells here are thinking about how to make the city 100% green and end car traffic within the city limits in favour of bicycles. The anti-litter programme here has also been implemented in San Francisco. You may not know it, but 80% of garbage is recycled and composted here. In 2020, they are aiming for 100%. If you do not play the game, you will get a fine of 800 USD. As for compost, it is partly recovered by the winemakers of Napa Valley, who convert to viticulture.

www.sanjoseca.gov/

content.title: The Parker Guest House: a sense of style

introduction.small: This gay-friendly bed and breakfast is open to people of all horizons, friends especially.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Parker Guest House: a sense of style

paragraphs.text:
Inevitably, you will have a lovely stay in this house, uniting two small Edwardian mansions. The hotel has an undeniable feeling of family or community and has many gay clients. Its rooms are large, which is rare in San Francisco, and tastefully furnished. You feel that the owners attach great attention to detail; bouquets of flowers or a blanket over a chair give you the finishing touch. You can enjoy the garden and the terrace, and then imbibe a glass of wine with guests in the evening while sharing your good addresses with them. You also have free access to the hammam. Breakfast is available in the morning, and you can have access to the kitchen to prepare some delicious sandwiches later in the day.

The Parker Guest House
520 Church Street
San Francisco, CA 94114

+1 415 621 3222

www.parkerguesthouse.com

Rooms: from 220 USD

content.title: De Young Museum: curios for the world curious

introduction.small: Imagine time travelling through eras in Oceania, Africa, and South America.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: De Young Museum: curios for the world curious

paragraphs.text:
From a distance, you imagine it to be built from the clay soil of the desert, but its copper colour is a trompe l'œil. The two famous Swiss architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron have given the museum a facelift, modernising the oldest art museum in San Francisco to meet seismic standards, thereby protecting its fabulous treasures from the wrath of the earth.

Dedicated to Africa, Oceania, and South America, the museum has amazing collections of paintings, ornaments, sculptures, and other rare items, as well as a very important heritage of drawings, archives, and photographs, all thanks to its 120-year existence. Established through donations from collectors but also adventurers themselves, you will enjoy imagining the travels that transported these items here. Who was Harriett Newton Dimond who travelled to late 19 th -century Papua New Guinea? Imagine also Charles Templeton Crocker, who went around the world on his yacht.

Temporary collections devoted to American heritage are also extensive: Hawaii feather ornaments and photographs taken by San Franciscan Willard Worden between 1900 and 1920.

De Young Museum
50 Hagiwara Tea Garden Dr
San Francisco, CA 94118

+1 415 750 3600

deyoung.famsf.org

content.title: Fairmont Hotel: the golden years

introduction.small: The history of San Francisco was written in this hotel, part and parcel of the city's heritage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fairmont Hotel: the golden years

paragraphs.text:
Do you know the Tony Bennett song 'I Left My Heart In San Francisco'? You'll lose yours here, or at least be so impressed with the setting that it will make you dizzy. This hotel, built just after the earthquake of 1906, cultivates the luxury of a city enriched by the Gold Rush. Everything is gilded here.

The vast marble lobby looks like a D. W. Griffith film set. Awe-inspiring! With its seven-metre high ceiling, gold damask dyes, and thick royal blue carpet with gold accents, the Venetian salon is a real ballroom.

The rooms are classic Victorian style, of discreet opulence with refined classic furniture in modern colours. The view of the bay will leave you with a nostalgic memory of early 19 th -century steamers. Even if you are not staying at the hotel, you can still discover the Hawaiian cuisine of its Tonga restaurant, and enjoy a lychee martini at the bar.

Fairmont Hotel
950 Mason Street
San Francisco, CA 94108

+1 415 772 5000

www.fairmont.com/san-francisco/

Rooms: from 399 USD

content.title: A real road show!

introduction.small: The Streets of San Francisco was a famous 1970s TV series. Indeed Lombard Street, Filbert Street, and Mission Street are as well-known as some Hollywood stars.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A real road show!

paragraphs.text:
They are part of the charm of this city and defy all laws of gravity. And of urbanism. They go in all directions, are of all lengths, all shapes. This is due both to the topography of San Francisco, mostly built on hills, and the clever minds of its civil engineers. Horses had to be accommodated and pedestrians had to navigate.

Hence, the sharp hairpin turns on Lombard Street that have inspired many indelible movies. Filbert Street is literally breath-taking with its gradient of 31.5%. The sidewalk is in fact a steep staircase. If you take the car, you need to park perpendicular to the curb, or the tow truck will be waiting. Mission Street has the record for length, at 11.5 kilometres. The widest is Van Ness Avenue at 38 metres. As for Harry Street, it has the greatest number of steps with a complete series of stairways. This climb between the gardens is lined with lovely houses.

content.title: Phoenix Hotel: the rock ‘n' roll attitude

introduction.small: This hotel owes its fame to the Red Hot Chilli Peppers and Pearl Jam, who stayed here before the hits rolled in.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Phoenix Hotel: the rock ‘n' roll attitude

paragraphs.text:
Just like the mythical bird after which it was named, the Phoenix Hotel underwent a complete makeover in 2018, under the creative and inspired impulse of Liz Lambert, one of the high priestesses of the trendy boutique hotel culture that flourished on the West Coast. She managed to retain the rock n' roll spirit of this former hostel, while adding a resolutely fashionable and cool touch to the proceedings. The lobby welcomes you in a recording studio look-alike, walls being covered with tons of records! The Phoenix still shows the signs of the various artists – famous or not – who stayed there: witness all the stickers, collector concert posters and the much-vaunted “Wall of fame” upon which everyone leaves a note or a drawing before checking out. Above the swimming pool, the passageways lead to 44 rooms: with white walls, electric blue headboards, pared-down contemporary furniture and colourful neon lights, the spirit of the Bowie years lives on! Plenty of activities are available: barbecues, yoga sessions and concerts regularly take place around the pool. Years have passed but the Phoenix stays true to its mantra: “be amazing”!

Phoenix Hotel
601 Eddy Street
San Francisco, CA 94109

+1 415 776 1380

www.phoenixsf.com

Rooms: from 270 USD

content.title: Cavallo Point Lodge: Yoga and Kung Fu in Sausalito

introduction.small: This lodge, formerly Officers' Quarters for the army, has a dramatic view of the San Francisco Bay and the Golden Gate Bridge.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cavallo Point Lodge: Yoga and Kung Fu in Sausalito

paragraphs.text:
These beautiful white houses, at the foot of the Golden Gate Bridge in Sausalito, cultivate a lodge ambiance as ecological as it is vintage. Originally an army base, the site retains the traditional charm of an officers' mess. You imagine yourself among these white-uniformed men and their wives in elegant dresses.

The rooms play on this past with vintage ceiling fans, wood-burning stoves, and cast-iron radiators, and they even have rocking chairs on the terrace. What a pleasure! You can also come for a healthy getaway.

While you may not have juicers in your suite, you will appreciate the sustainable architecture of the contemporary buildings, the gas fireplace inserts, and bamboo panelling. Yoga classes are included in some packages; however, you need to register for the Kung Fu.

Cavallo Point Lodge
601 Murray Circle
Fort Baker
Sausalito, CA 94965

+1 415 339 4700

www.cavallopoint.com

Rooms: from 580 USD

content.title: Mama's for brunch: you won't regret it

introduction.small: Regulars wait hours in line for the pleasure of devouring an omelette, some pancakes, or French toast.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mama's for brunch: you won't regret it

paragraphs.text:
At the corner of Washington Square, in addition to its green blinds, how will you recognize Mama's? Its legendary line will tip you off. A total of three generations of the Sanchez family has gotten up at dawn to prepare breakfast. The speciality of the house? The omelettes, which are available in ten variations, and the eggs Benedict, which come in almost as many.

You will have your dose of protein and lipids, too, as you will not be able to resist the delicious fried potatoes. You can also opt for a Caesar salad, or enjoy the delicious pancakes of the house, unless you prefer French toast or carrot cake. Each dessert is a cruel incentive to gluttony that you will not be able to resist especially when you see your fellow diners' eyes shining with pleasure.

Mama's
1071 Stockton Street
San Francisco, CA 94133

+1 415 362 6421

www.mamas-sf.com

Menu: around 15 USD

content.title: Greens Restaurant: the forward-thinking old guard

introduction.small: Gourmet vegetarian cuisine has its roots in this restaurant, one of the founders of the movement.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Greens Restaurant: the forward-thinking old guard

paragraphs.text:
Even if you are not a vegetarian, you ought to make the trip to this classic restaurant in the former barracks at Fort Mason. You will have an exceptional view of the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge here at Greens, which has been run for almost 40 years by one of the leaders of the vegetarian movement.

Annie Somerville is inspired by world cuisines to imagine colourful and uninhibited dishes, but she sources her ingredients locally. Sonoma artisans even made the furniture. The menu sticks to the seasons and is developed according to market availability. Do not be surprised if it varies depending on the green grocer's ‘catch of the day', from endives to Brussels sprouts to kale.

The dishes are hearty and satiating, always accompanied by cereals and often cheese. You can even try some egg sausages. Since the produce is of the best quality, the result is intensely flavourful, from the tomatoes and lettuce down to even the parsley. The result is delicious food!

Greens Restaurant
A, Fort Mason, 2 Marina Blvd
San Francisco, CA 94123

+1 415 771 6222

www.greensrestaurant.com

Menu: around 25 USD

content.title: Big Sur: a wild coast

introduction.small: Between the Redwood trees and the ocean air, an unexplored feeling haunts this savage coast, buffeted by the wind and the waves of the Pacific.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Big Sur: a wild coast

paragraphs.text:
Big Sur is the name of 140 kilometres of cliffs that drop straight into the ocean between Carmel and San Simeon. Gold miners once roamed this land, but it is difficult to access. The famous highway from San Francisco was built in 1937, but electricity was only installed in the 1950s.

Big Sur, which had been abandoned since the Gold Rush, then became the favourite residence of writers. Jack Kerouac wrote Big Sur right here. Rare is the traveller who does not stop at the Henry Miller Memorial Library. The writer feared that this region would become a suburb of Monterey, but it did not.

When you cross this scenery between sea and forest, you are literally bewitched by its authenticity. When you disappear among the Redwoods of the Julia Pfeiffer Burns State Park, you will have little chance of seeing the lynx and cougars, but you will feel their presence. As for the houses, they are well hidden. You can sleep in one of the few hotels, the Post Ranch Inn, for example, or go on a retreat at the New Camaldoli Hermitage.

content.title: POPOS: the secrets of San Francisco

introduction.small: These are private spaces in which you can take a break, read the newspaper and admire a stunning view of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: POPOS: the secrets of San Francisco

paragraphs.text:
Since ‘Privately Owned Public Open Space' is such a mouthful, these hidden spots have become known as POPOS. A square, a garden, the hall of a building, a terrace on a roof or the boardroom of a company. Officially, they do not exist, and are not accessible. However, you need no key nor code to get in.

Everyone knows about them, off the record. Enjoy them as all residents of San Francisco do. You will see locals lunching here or drinking their lattes. Sometimes parties are organised.

How can you find them? They are of course not clearly identified, but their location, which used to be under the seal of secrecy, has now been revealed. There are now guides that identify these 68 places, for the most part located in the Financial District. Grab one to visit a different side of San Francisco.

www.spur.org

content.title: Chez Panisse: the holy grail of slow food

introduction.small: Alice Waters' ice cream with wild blackberries has become a legend in California, and Michelle Obama even created an organic garden at the White House under her inspiration.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez Panisse: the holy grail of slow food

paragraphs.text:
Alice Waters has been fighting a war against American junk food for 40 years. She is credited as one of the founders of the ‘farm-to-table' movement that is now present throughout the country. Believers think that, for your health and for the good of society, both at home and out on the town, you should attempt to eat simple, fresh cuisine made with products grown nearby. Chez Panisse is a tribute not only to the South of France of Marcel Pagnol but also to the meaning of friendship and community.

From the outside, be careful not to miss the restaurant, as it is hidden behind an imposing gate. The upstairs is only open in the evenings and offers a unique menu that changes daily. The spirit is gourmet with a French influence; indeed, the book that is never far out of Waters' reach is La Bonne Cuisine de Madame E. Saint-Ange (originally published in France in 1927 and now available in English).

The downstairs bistro offers a shorter menu, whose refinement you will also appreciate. All meals are served with radishes, because Alice Waters is passionate about these slightly peppery vegetables.

Chez Panisse
1517 Shattuck Avenue
Berkeley, CA 94709

+1 510 548 5525

www.chezpanisse.com

Menu: around 100 USD

content.title: Rintaro: the best Japanese restaurant in San Francisco

introduction.small: Japanese cuisine is local when made in California. Come and see.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rintaro: the best Japanese restaurant in San Francisco

paragraphs.text:
His mother is Japanese; his father is American. He grew up in the US in a wooden house built by his father, where his mother prepared traditional Japanese cuisine. In the summer, Sylvan Brackett spent his holidays with his grandmother in Kyoto. There he fell in love with its cuisine. You find all these influences in his restaurant, designed as a traditional Japanese house with its oven in the garden. Come in. You are in a real minka ('house of the people'). Partitions separate the tables.

Behind the counter, the chef kneads the dough for noodles and prepares the soups and sashimi. You will be amazed by the originality of the tempura and yakitori. They are prepared only from local produce. Nothing is imported. Kumquats replace yuzu. Rintaro has received the congratulations of the entire American press. Take a look at the fine collection of plates, dishes, and menus that make for a decor with an authentic soul.

Rintaro
82 14th Street
San Francisco, CA 94103

+1 415 589 7022

www.izakayarintaro.com

Menu: around 15 USD

content.title: Frances: the lady of Castro

introduction.small: At 25, Melissa Perello was the executive chef of Charles in Nob Hill before taking the helm at Fifth Floor. Now, happily, she has her own place.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Frances: the lady of Castro

paragraphs.text:
Suffice it to say that San Francisco was on high alert when Melissa Perello decided to strike out on her own and open a restaurant in the Castro District. If you want to discover what California cuisine really is, this is where you need to go.

The bistro menu, minimalist design, sublime dishes, and, according to its regulars, service that is near perfection make it a poster child for today's food. Of course, the chef only works with regional products. The fish come from Monterey, the poultry from Sonoma. The names of the farms are even mentioned on the menu, and the cooking is truly creative.

The crunchy chickpea fries eaten at the bar with your fingers will surprise you. Try the kale salad with crispy shallots and blue cheese. The vegetarian dishes deserve their culinary acclaim. As for the meats, a cooking secret brings out their incredible taste. You can finish with a pear and pistachio pavlova or a fig and ganache truffle chocolate ice cream with slivers of mint, all accompanied by wines from the Napa Valley.

Frances
3870 17th Street
San Francisco, CA 94114

+1 415 621 3870

www.frances-sf.com

Menu: around 30 USD

content.title: Lord Stanley: new California cuisine

introduction.small: San Francisco is the home of cuisine introduced by young chefs like Carrie and Rupert Blease.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lord Stanley: new California cuisine

paragraphs.text:
A harmony of white, light grey, and wood. As soon as you get through the door, you will notice that this restaurant has a Scandinavian air to it. Carrie and Rupert Blease are, however, full-blooded Americans.

After having trained with different European chefs, particularly in England, and then in New York, they opened this San Francisco restaurant. Everything is homemade, including the bread, the butter, and even the herbal teas. If you must choose between lunch and dinner, go for dinner, as this will give you time to really enjoy their cuisine.

It resembles San Francisco, between sea and land, and is imbued with European influences. The menu is small but goes straight to the well- conceived tasting menu. Poached oysters with seaweed and cucumber are a real treat. The smoked cod, served with borlotti bean curry and black olives, is delicate and scrumptious, and the Wagyu beef with white truffle is glorious. Want some more?

Lord Stanley
2065 Polk Street
San Francisco, CA 94109

+1 415 872 5512

www.lordstanleysf.com

Menu: around 31 USD

content.title: Clift Royal Sonesta Hotel: out of a dream

introduction.small: In the Theater District, this hotel by Philippe Starck could be a stage set.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Clift Royal Sonesta Hotel: out of a dream

paragraphs.text:
The surrealist decor of the lobby, complete with a stool by Salvador Dali, leads you into a totally dream-like state. And what is more natural in a place dedicated to sleep? Starck brought his signature items here: large mirrors, Murano glass chandeliers, and an outsized chair. The rooms meet the most demanding specifications. Decorated with opulence, they remain places of rest. It is with pleasure that you will let yourself go to the arms of Morpheus among silk, velvet, and leather in tones of ivory, grey, and lavender that are all conducive to a good night's sleep. But first, you have to take the time to dive into another nocturnal atmosphere, that of the Redwood Room. This bar is a legend in San Francisco, with its redwood panelling made from just one tree. The setting is glorious. Have a vodka martini and relax for a moment, but know that after 9:00 p.m. the place becomes a nightclub.

Clift Royal Sonesta Hotel
495 Geary Street
San Francisco, CA 94102

+1 415 775 4700

https://www.sonesta.com/us/california/san-francisco/clift-royal-sonesta-hotel

Rooms: from 215 USD

content.title: La Ciccia: a return to Sardinia

introduction.small: This small neighbourhood restaurant has a large reputation with food lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Ciccia: a return to Sardinia

paragraphs.text:
There are just 40 seats, not one more! The room is small and cosy, and you immediately feel as if you're in Italy or, more specifically, in Sardinia especially if you are located anywhere near the kitchen. Massimiliano Conti, who is in the kitchen, regularly puts his head in the room and makes comments in an Italian accent that you can cut with a knife. The menu is written in a Sardinian dialect but is wisely translated by his wife Lorella Degan.

While awaiting your linguine with bottarga or your octopus stew with tomato, which you will later shower with the most extreme possible superlatives, down a few slices of delicious mortadella or pancetta. You can also take a pizza with olives and capers while choosing from one of the 180 vintages on the wine list, which features a good selection of Sardinian reds. Finish with a ricotta rosemary cake with saffron ice cream, which you will not soon forget, and then remind yourself that you had to wait for your trip to San Francisco to enjoy such a wonder.

La Ciccia
291 30th Street
San Francisco, CA 94131

+1 415 550 8114

www.laciccia.com

Menu: around 30 USD

content.title: Alcatraz: the prison across the bay

introduction.small: This former high-security setting of numerous films is one of the most visited sites in San prison, the Francisco.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Alcatraz: the prison across the bay

paragraphs.text:
No one escapes from Alcatraz. Except in the movies. Clint Eastwood starred in a 1979 film that chronicles the true story of the escape of his character, Frank Morris, along with the Anglin brothers. The prisoners expanded air vents with spoons and crossed the icy waters on a boat made with inmates' rain jackets. But despite an extensive manhunt, the trio has never been found.

Recently, a Dutch team of meteorologists modelled ocean currents and showed that a departure from ‘the rock' between 11 p.m. and midnight that day had every chance of success. One year after the incredible escape, high maintenance costs and a poor reputation led to the closing of the 30-year-old, high-security prison. Alcatraz is now one of the main attractions in San Francisco. Artist Ai Weiwei, once imprisoned in China, recently presented seven installations here including Lego portraits of 176 political prisoners.

Alcatraz Island
Bay Street and Embarcadero
Pier 33 Alcatraz Landing
San Francisco, CA 94133

+1 415 981 7625

https://www.nps.gov/alca/index.htm

content.title: Wasteland, temple of vintage clothing

introduction.small: From Marc Jacobs to Vivienne Westwood, designers of all stripes come to check out the boutique that brought on the vintage moment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wasteland, temple of vintage clothing

paragraphs.text:
A reaction to ‘institutions' of all kinds brought about the thrift shop trend in the 1970s. A dozen years ago the vintage movement began. The difference between vintage and retro? Vintage styles are throwbacks to the1960s. This trend emerged in Los Angeles where Joe Swinney and Cheryl Cohen had their first shop before opening the one in San Francisco. They have a predilection for hippie clothes and rock outfits, but also western styles.

You should avoid the total look. To do so, vintage pieces have to be mixedin: a belt, a shirt, a skirt, can be worn with your brand-new jeans for instance. The idea is to create your own style and to be unique; nobody should look just like you. You can sell your clothing at Wasteland too. If you are interested in the fashion world, know that many designers and stylists come here to seek inspiration for their own collections.

Wasteland
1660 Haight Street
San Francisco, CA 94117

+1 415 863 3150

www.shopwasteland.com

content.title: The Golden Gate Bridge: an icon worth its weight in…

introduction.small: Named for the maritime strait that links San Francisco Bay to the Pacific Ocean.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Golden Gate Bridge: an icon worth its weight in…

paragraphs.text:
John Frémont, the first Republican nominee for the US presidency, named this strait the ‘golden gate', even before the gold rush! The bridge to cross far above was added more than 80 years later, between 1933 and 1937, when San Francisco had become a respectable and respected city on the West Coast.

The Golden Gate Bridge is the universally known symbol of San Francisco, just as the Eiffel Tower is of Paris. You will immediately recognize its intense ‘international orange' colour. Connecting San Francisco to Sausalito, it was the longest suspension bridge in the world for many years. The bridge is not only part of the local landscape: since Alfred Hitchcock filmed Vertigo, in which Jimmy Stewart jumped into the bay to save Kim Novak from drowning beneath the bridge, the icon has had its own leading role in popular culture.

The Golden Gate Quartet, one of the oldest continuously active gospel groups, was formed at the time of the bridge's construction and took their name from it.

Golden Gate Bridge
Lincoln Boulevard (near Doyle Drive and Fort Point)
San Francisco, CA 94129

+1 415 921 5858

www.goldengatebridge.org

content.title: Haight-Ashbury: for the hippie in you

introduction.small: In 1967, 100,000 hippies invaded San Francisco, meeting at the Intersection of Haight and Ashbury streets for the gigantic happening that is remembered as the Summer of Love.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Haight-Ashbury: for the hippie in you

paragraphs.text:
Originally, hippies and beatniks lived in North Beach, but the increase in rents in that area brought them here where the colourful, more or less abandoned houses seemed as psychedelic as the drugs did. Janis Joplin lived at 635 Ashbury and Jimi Hendrix gave his first concert on the lawn just across the street. Half a century later, the houses are still here, and you may even rent one for your vacation.

The Haight district has not changed all that much. You can still be a free-love fan here, exploring the vintage thrift shops, independent bookstores, tattoo parlours, music stores and more. Poke your head into the shops and take home some spiritualism with a pack of incense. A moment to reconnect with youthful dreams and to wonder…

content.title: ABV: beer or a cocktail?

introduction.small: This bar belongs to three gurus of California mixology.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: ABV: beer or a cocktail?

paragraphs.text:
Ryan Fitzgerald, Erik Reichborn-Kjennerud, and Kevin Cimino wanted a place that was like no other, neither retro, nor vintage, nor design. It had to be ‘trend-free' they explain, leaning on the long counter. Depending on what time you come, you will be surprised by the atmosphere, which changes according to the intensity of the light reflected in the large mirrors hung like paintings on the walls. You will never be disappointed by the quality and originality of their cocktails, some of which play the card of naturalness and are made with fresh fruit juices prepared to order. Also on the menu is one of the great wines of Napa Valley, Matthiasson, and small-batch beers, like Moonlight Brewing. Instead of standing at the bar, sit at one of the long tables d'hôte. You can share a few bites here, like canapés that mix Asian, American, and Mexican influences. Authentic fusion finger food! Sunday brunch is great, too.

ABV
3174 16th Street
San Francisco, CA 94103

+1 415 400 4748

www.abvsf.com

Menu: from 10 USD

content.title: Mission Cliffs: adventure for adventure's sake

introduction.small: In San Francisco, you don't play baseball, soccer, or basketball. If you like the sea, you surf, if you like the mountains, you climb.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mission Cliffs: adventure for adventure's sake

paragraphs.text:
Vertical Limit is the cult film for some and Point Break for others. Here you can learn about rock climbing, the preferred outdoor sport of city dwellers, along with surfing and biking. The steep streets of the city are already an excellent cardio workout, as is a mountain-bike crossing of the Golden Gate Bridge, but to really put yourself to the test, head to a climbing gym.

Mission Cliffs is a favourite of climbers because of a wall, more than 15 metres high, which is built in a way that allows the replication of famous rocks, thereby reproducing specific climbs. This is a team sport and solidarity is one of the values advocated by California ‘yuccies'—young urban creatives.

Once you are trained here, you can go for the real thing at Joshua Tree, Indian Rock, or Castle Rock. Rock climbing is a sport that you will love to practice, as it forges impressive muscle firmness. In addition, it is inseparable from the practice of yoga for flexibility and balance.

Mission Cliffs
2295 Harrison Street
San Francisco, CA 94110

+1 415 550 0515

www.touchstoneclimbing.com

content.title: Hotel G: typically San Franciscan

introduction.small: If you wish to dive into an authentic atmosphere, come on down.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel G: typically San Franciscan

paragraphs.text:
At the corner of Geary and Mason Street, this hotel, built in 1909, was home to poet Robert Peterson when he was growing up. Its atmosphere inspired many of his works, as did the clientele of boxers and jazz musicians. Time has passed, and the place has changed, while keeping the feeling of a family guesthouse.

If you like modernity without bluster, this is the place for you. The rooms are bright, comfortable, and finished with small touches that create the warmth of the place, such as patterned carpets and chairs in a Nordic spirit.

You will feel at home. On the ground floor was one of the most typical steakhouses in San Francisco, emblazoned on many a vintage postcard, but it has now been turned into a café that offers food for today, simple and healthy. Tastes are no longer what they were…

Hotel G
386 Geary Street
San Francisco, CA 94102

+1 415 986 2000

www.hotelgsanfrancisco.com

Rooms: from 211 USD

content.title: Hotel Vertigo: for a taste of the past

introduction.small: This classic hotel served as the set for Vertigo, the famous Hitchcock movie.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Vertigo: for a taste of the past

paragraphs.text:
The Hitchcock movie is continually on screen in the lobby, but since the filming, the hotel has been renamed and renovated by the Californian designer Thomas Schoos. If you want to spend a few nights in a typical San Francisco place, you are at the right address.

While the rooms up the wide staircase are not very big, they have the spirit of apartments as they were half a century ago, with shag carpets in some and Victorian chairs in vibrant orange in others. As usual on the West Coast, white dominates, though the very authentic touches make the hotel feel like a special getaway.

All this gives the hotel the feeling of a movie set, though it doesn't push it too far. You can always try to book room 501! This is where Scottie, aka Jimmy Stewart, finds Madeleine, who is later Judy, both played by Kim Novak.

Hotel Vertigo
940 Sutter Street
San Francisco, CA 94109

+1 415 885 6800

www.hotelvertigosf.com

Rooms: from 150 USD

content.title: Hotel des Arts: with a comics spirit

introduction.small: You will sleep amidst a wealth of art. Each room has personalised decor signed by an artist who draws comic books or paints graffiti.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel des Arts: with a comics spirit

paragraphs.text:
With a French name, as it is in the French Quarter, this hotel is dedicated to art, but it may not be to your taste if you only like classical paintings from the Louvre. Indeed, you are in an alternative culture here.

Artists whose works are graffiti, graphic design, or silk screens have decorated all the rooms. Some are famous. The muralist Shepard Fairey, whose Hope portrait of Barack Obama is iconic, decorated room 210. Plasticgod signed the cartoon atmosphere of room 312.

Don't worry: none will trigger insomnia, but it may not be easy to book a particular room in advance. You may sleep with the hounds while you prefer ‘Kauai'. On the practical side, some have their own bathrooms, while others share. This place will remind you of your years of boarding school, but a little bit crazier.

Hotel des Arts
447 Bush Street
San Francisco, CA 94168

+1 415 956 3232

https://www.sfhoteldesarts.com/en-us

Rooms: from 200 USD

content.title: Chinatown: the largest in America

introduction.small: What language is spoken here? Mandarin? Cantonese? English? You can find out for yourself in this city within a city after you pass under the Dragon Gate.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chinatown: the largest in America

paragraphs.text:
The United States was indeed truly united once the first train arrived, connecting the East and West Coasts. Thousands of Chinese came for the work of constructing the railway, migrating to America during the years of the Taiping Rebellion in the mid-19th century. The earliest arrivals, two men and a woman, came in 1848. Thus Chinatown was born and developed as a city within a city. At the time, migrants lived separately, had their own banks, their own schools.

Today you still enter through the Dragon Gate that is bordered by two lion statues on Grant Avenue. The classic visit starts at St. Mary's Park for the statue of Sun Yat-sen, then goes to Portsmouth Square for the mah-jong parties and tai-chi sessions, and the headquarters of the Bank of Canton, the Sing Chong Building, for its architecture. You can buy lucky fortune cookies, and in one of the many herbalists, remedies against minor ailments. Also enjoy a reflexology session. A trend from yesterday for today.

Chinatown
Grant Avenue
San Francisco, CA 94108

www.sanfranciscochinatown.com

content.title: Berkeley: 65 Nobel prizes, 19 Oscars, and 11 Pulitzers

introduction.small: When studying in the United States, the American Dream is alive and well.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Berkeley: 65 Nobel prizes, 19 Oscars, and 11 Pulitzers

paragraphs.text:
This is the campus where protests against the Vietnam War began in the 1960s, a place that remains one of the most progressive of American universities, with 92% of its students voting Democrat.

Admission is incredibly difficult and students are therefore of the highest levels. Berkeley is in the top three best universities in the world and is among the most cosmopolitan. No less than 46% of its first-year students are children of Chinese, Vietnamese, Korean, and Japanese immigrants. If you want to spend a semester or more here, it is not mission impossible, provided you target your department.

The campus is huge and each department, each laboratory is independent. There are 14 faculties, including the law school, founded in 1881. If you register at Berkeley, you will meet a host of researchers, professors, and students, and you will build an international network of personalities who may well be among the most influential in your discipline.

University of California at Berkeley
101 Sproul Hall
Berkeley, CA 94700

+1 510 642 6000

www.berkeley.edu

content.title: Ferry Plaza Farmers' Market: welcome to the farm!

introduction.small: Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturday mornings, close to 80 farmers from around San Francisco come to sell their products on this organic certified market.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ferry Plaza Farmers' Market: welcome to the farm!

paragraphs.text:
This is another of the peculiarities of San Francisco. You can go directly from the city to the countryside in certain places. Since the early 1980s, many city dwellers have converted urban land into farms. All with organic agriculture and sustainable techniques.

Every Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday morning, they come to the pier to sell their products. This is where the wave of kale worship was born. Depending on the season, you will find melons or apples, vegetables galore, especially fragrant herbs, eggs and, in season, many varieties of mushrooms. A group of 40 producers banded together to create the Cow Girl dairy cooperative.

Do not hesitate to taste their stilton, cheddar, and even their Roquefort! On Saturday, all the chefs of San Francisco head to the market, which is also a gathering place for local food trucks. Feeling hungry? Have a taco or a burger, but beware of the seagulls' voracious appetite!

Ferry Plaza Farmers Market
1 Ferry Building, n° 50
San Francisco, CA 94111

+1 415 291 3276

www.ferrybuildingmarketplace.com

content.title: Lake Tahoe: a weekend in the green

introduction.small: Since everyone heads to Yosemite, opt to avoid the crowds and head to Tahoe for some fishing, boating, and relaxing on one of the most beautiful lakes in America.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lake Tahoe: a weekend in the green

paragraphs.text:
Mark Twain called this lake ‘the most beautiful place the earth affords' adding that the air was ‘the same air as the angels breathe.' At 250 kilometres from San Francisco, near the California border with Nevada, Lake Tahoe is considered the most magical lake in the United States. Its water is so transparent that it perfectly reflects the sky, making it a unique and beautiful emerald blue. Mountains rising to 3,000 metres surrounded it, and in the winter you can ski at Heavenly or Northstar California resorts.

In summer, whether on foot, by bike, or on horseback, you can follow the 266 kilometres of trails. Some sections show the paths followed by either the Washoe Indians, the first pioneers, or Basque shepherds. If you do not have the time or energy for a long adventure, know that the chair lifts provide access to various hiking areas.

From its shore, you can indulge in some sailing, paddling, and kayaking. Or hang your hat at Emerald Bay and rent a trapper's cabin. In the evening, in a plaid shirt and a Stetson, you can grill your rainbow trout with a wink at John Wayne.

www.visitinglaketahoe.com

content.title: International Orange: body and mind

introduction.small: This spa is known as the best in San Francisco as much for its aromatic treatments as for its yoga classes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: International Orange: body and mind

paragraphs.text:
Named after the distinctive colour of the Golden Gate Bridge, International Orange suggests a yoga class before a treatment or a massage. A few sun salutations will relax you, facilitate the evacuation of toxins, and relax your skin, your body, and your mind. You will also be more receptive to the benefits of plant extracts and essential oils that the therapist will apply for 90 minutes.

With Signature Facial care for men and women, you will have a clear and rested face, with a cranberry-seed exfoliation and a divinely refreshing papaya-pineapple mask. With its extracts of flowers, the Flore Facial will give you a healthy complexion.

In case of jet lag, go for a head and foot massage. If you feel tired, try the massage with basalt river stones. After your session, you can relax with an herbal tea suited to your metabolism on the wooden deck of the spa.

International Orange
2044 Fillmore Street
San Francisco, CA 94115

+1 415 563 5000

www.internationalorange.com

content.title: Napa Valley: valley of wine

introduction.small: What is the most visited Northern Californian destination? Napa Valley, of course. Or head to the Sonoma wineries, too, and stay off the beaten path.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Napa Valley: valley of wine

paragraphs.text:
A famous anecdote tells of an international wine magazine conducting a blind test for the best 2005 vintages. Of 15 wines chosen, five were from California. Nobody now disputes the quality of wines from Napa Valley that, like almost all wine-growing regions, has extensive wine tourism. From San Francisco, you can head to Napa or to Sonoma. In particular, do not miss Beaulieu Vineyard, one of the oldest, founded in 1885 by a French couple. They have also been voted the best winery to visit; when you go, taste their excellent Cabernets. Of course, you can also stop in the vineyard of Francis Ford Coppola or at Domaine Chandon, another great choice. Young winemakers have partnered to open the Dashe Cellars wine cooperative in Oakland. You will discover lesser-known wines there, full of character and future.

Dashe Cellars
55 Fourth Street
Oakland, CA 94607

+1 510 452 1800

content.title: Rich Table: need we say more?

introduction.small: Like many food capitals, San Francisco is under the spell of a new generation of chefs.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rich Table: need we say more?

paragraphs.text:
Have you noticed that, in many new restaurants, the chefs are often a couple, a formula that seems to work quite well? Evan and Sarah Rich are no exception to this trend; at their eponymously named place they propose a particularly innovative cuisine focusing on flavours and combinations of flavours that are often surprising. One of Evan's specialities-his signature dish-is a plate of sardine chips accompanied by horseradish cream. You have most certainly not seen this elsewhere. Their filet of cod in vin jaune wine, chanterelle mushrooms and apples is remarkable, the foie gras with raisins and spicy peanuts is surprisingly exquisite, and the short ribs, served with a homemade bittersweet barbecue sauce, are very appetizing. All of this works very well, obviously. Would you have thought of it?

Rich Table
199 Gough Street
San Francisco, CA 94102

+1 415 355 9085

www.richtablesf.com

Menu: around 60 USD

content.title: Amoeba: the temple of music

introduction.small: If you are looking for a 1972 vinyl disc by the Rolling Stones, you will be sure to find it here in this massive music shop in Berkeley.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Amoeba: the temple of music

paragraphs.text:
You have never seen such stacks of albums and tapes, over 100,000 in all. Everything is here, hard rock, soul, and R ‘n' B. You'd like to find Summertime by Janis Joplin recorded in Frankfurt on 11 April 1969? Here it is! Or the original edition of the White Album by the Beatles?

If you are a huge fan of Peter Tosh or Clancy Eccles, you will find your alter ego amongst one of the staff; they have an incredible music culture. When they are not behind the bins, they are either in concert halls or in the recording studios. Amoeba has become such an institution that some artists perform here; there have been jam sessions with the likes of Lana del Rey and others. And in the Los Angeles shop, Stella McCartney, worthy daughter of her father, recently presented her ready-to-wear collection.

Amoeba
1855 Haight Street
San Francisco, CA 94117

+1 415 831 1200

www.amoeba.com

content.title: General Store: locavore shopping

introduction.small: This concept store highlights the new Californian spirit that encourages a return to locally made products.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: General Store: locavore shopping

paragraphs.text:
Whether in fashion or design, America is rediscovering its history, going back to the past in search of authenticity. This concept store perfectly illustrates this phenomenon. In addition to their selection of objects, what is very important for Serena Mitnik-Miller and Mason St. Peter is the feeling you experience in their shop, a space in which you feel your best. The wooden racks are made of redwood and the plants bring you an air of serenity while they aerate the rooms.

Presented here are only brands manufactured in California and inspired by local know-how. Enjoy the KL ceramics, by potter Kelly Lamb. You will love the delicate earrings of Kathleen Whitaker, and the collection of hand-dyed indigo clothes and curtains by Lookout & Wonderland. They make you want to transform your interior, and plant seeds of desert flowers on your windowsills.

General Store
4035 Judah Street
San Francisco, CA 94122

+1 415 682 0600

www.shop-generalstore.com

content.title: Walt Disney Family Museum: pure family fun

introduction.small: After a visit here, you will have just one idea in mind, to see the masterpieces of ‘Fantasia' and ‘The Jungle Book', over and over again.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Walt Disney Family Museum: pure family fun

paragraphs.text:
After visiting Disneyland in Los Angeles (or not), come behind the scenes in this museum dedicated to the father of Mickey, Mr. Walt Disney himself. His daughter Diana is behind this museum, and she financed it with her own funds. It is located in the Presidio Park, which was also partly designed by the Disney family. From the outside it looks more like an office building than a museum.

Yet once inside you will see all the awards given to the creator of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. You immerse yourself in his life and work through pictures and home movies, some of which had never been shown until the opening of the museum.

Even if you are not an expert in animation, the creative work you see here, the design, development, and assembly of the animation, as well as its digitisation, will all fascinate you. The exhibits are all interactive using new technologies, which makes this visit as fun for your family as the latest cartoon.

Walt Disney Family Museum
104 Montgomery Street
San Francisco, CA 94129

+1 415 345 6800

www.waltdisney.org/

content.title: HI San Francisco Downtown: a return to the 1970s

introduction.small: In San Francisco, you can't escape the 1970s, especially in a youth hostel!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: HI San Francisco Downtown: a return to the 1970s

paragraphs.text:
If you are a young backpacker, you may be following in the footsteps of your grandparents who took the road to Kathmandu just a handful of decades ago. You probably share the same pleasure in meeting new friends, listening to music and remaking the world as they did. That is exactly what you will do when you find yourself in this hostel. Besides its vintage decoration, it has preserved the feeling of the 1970s and not just because you are listening to the Doors and Led Zeppelin!

This state of mind is likely cultivated by the view of the ocean as you look out your bedroom window. Whether in a private or shared room, all have a pleasant view of the bay. In the fog, you can hang out in the spacious living room in front of the wood stove while someone plays the piano.

In good weather, take one of the bikes available and go for a ride. Upon your return, you can improvise your own meal in the professionally equipped kitchen!

HI San Francisco Downtown
312 Mason Street
San Francisco, CA 94102

+1 415 788 5604

www.hihostels.com

Rooms: from 70 USD

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN San Francisco
content.introduction: Surrounded by water on three sides, San Francisco's climate can generally be classified as Mediterranean, thus characterized by temperate, wet winters and warm, dry summers. Temperatures hardly ever fall below freezing in the winter months and it seldom snows. The famous fog that often covers the San Francisco Bay Area rolls in as often in summer as in winter. Heat waves are exceedingly rare in San Francisco. September and October are the hottest months of the year.

airports.title: San Francisco International Airport
airports.description:
San Francisco International Airport is located 21 kilometres (13 miles) south of the city centre.
  • Four terminals:
    • Terminal International (Air France)
    • Terminal 1
    • Terminal 2
    • Terminal 3

Getting from the airport to San Francisco and back
  • By car
    • Accessible via Highway 101, about 20 minutes to the city centre.
    • Several parking facilities are available at the airport:
      • Cell Phone Waiting Lot, free of charge for a maximum wait time of 60 minutes (vehicles must not be left unattended).
      • Domestic and International Garages for short-term parking, USD 2 for 15 minutes.
      • Long-term Garage and Overflow Parking, USD 25 for 24 hours.
    • Several car rental companies have counters at the airport's Rental Car Center, accessible from the airport terminals by taking the AirTrain Blue Line.
  • By rail
    • Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) operates convenient and inexpensive rapid rail services to several destinations in the city centre as well as surrounding areas directly from the airport (about a 30-minute ride).
    • Trains run from 4 a.m. to midnight Monday to Friday, 6 a.m. to midnight Saturday and 8 a.m. to midnight Sunday and holidays.
    • Fare between USD 2 and USD 10, depending on the distance.
  • By SupperShuttle
    • Shuttle service connecting the airport to passenger destination from 8 a.m. to midnight. USD 17 each way.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the central island outside the arrivals hall in each terminal.
    • Fares to the city centre average USD 40, plus tip
  • Services: boutiques, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) at the airport.
  • Telephone: +1 650 821 8211

Website: www.flysfo.com

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN San Francisco
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in San Francisco each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: Third Monday in January : Martin Luther King Day (Martin Luther King Day) (national holiday)
events.description: A federal holiday in the United States, celebrating the life and achievements of Martin Luther King, Jr. In recent years, it has increasingly been seen as a day of service, when Americans are encouraged to volunteer to help others less fortunate than themselves. In San Francisco, many of the commemorative events take place in Yerba Buena Gardens, where a large memorial dedicated to Martin Luther King, Jr. is located.

events.title: January/February : Chinese New Year (celebrated nationwide in major cities)
events.description: Today, San Francisco's Chinese community is the second largest outside Asia. As the city's Chinatown was the first permanent urban settlement established by Chinese immigrants in the New World, the Chinese New Year is a major annual festival in San Francisco. Celebrations include a mammoth parade, featuring a 200-foot golden dragon carried by a team of a hundred people and a street fair featuring Chinese cultural arts, such as lantern- and kite-making, calligraphy, folk dancing, puppet shows, acrobats and magicians.

events.title: July 4 : Independence Day (national holiday)
events.description: A federal holiday in the United States commemorating the adoption of the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776, by which the 13 American colonies officially severed their political ties with Great Britain. Celebrated in San Francisco and throughout the Bay Area with parades, picnics, concerts, family fun and fireworks.

events.title: Second Monday in October : Columbus Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the landing of Christopher Columbus in the New World (October 12, 1492). Initially, festivities on this day celebrated Italian-American heritage, but with expanding ethnic diversity in the traditionally Italian North Beach neighbourhood of the city crossed by the parade, they now include more of a focus on dialogue between San Francisco's many different communities.

events.title: October 31 : Halloween (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Halloween is celebrated each year by Americans of all ages. In the late afternoon and early evening hours, children don costumes and go door-to-door in their neighbourhoods to ask for treats, typically candy. Adults often attend costume parties in the evening. In San Francisco, many residents really get into the spirit, transforming their homes with over-the-top special effects and decorations.

events.title: Fourth Thursday in November: Thanksgiving (national holiday)
events.description: Originally a Christian religious observance, for many years Thanksgiving has been a secular holiday in the United States, celebrated by Americans of all faiths. Families come together to prepare and enjoy a large feast at home. The meal typically includes roast turkey with stuffing, mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce as well as various side dishes and ends with an assortment of pies (pumpkin, pecan, apple).

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for the United States
administrativeProcedures.description:
The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) allows citizens of participating countries to travel to the United States without a visa for stays of 90 days or less, whether for tourism or business. Two requirements must be met:

  • Your passport must meet the criteria for VWP travel (it must be machine-readable, with an integrated chip containing information from the passport data page). For further information, visit the Visa Waiver Program page on the website of the Bureau of Consular Affairs, U.S. Department of State: travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/us-visas/tourism-visit/visa-waiver-program.html
  • You must have a valid Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) prior to travel. For further information, visit the ESTA page on the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) website: http://www.cbp.gov/travel/international-visitors/esta

Travellers not eligible for the VWP, or who have not been able to obtain an ESTA, must apply for a visa.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in San Francisco and the United States, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful is also provided on the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ website:

View information for travellers to the United States.

End of daylight saving time: first Sunday in November
goodToKnow.tips:
And what about tipping?
In San Francisco as in the rest of the United States, a service charge is not included in the bill and tips form a major portion of income for waiting staff. Prices on restaurant menus are indicated before taxes and tips. You are therefore expected to leave a tip (generally between 15 and 20 percent of the bill). Tipping less than 15 percent (or leaving no tip at all) means that you are very dissatisfied with the service.
